questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of multiple right inframammary lumps. They are tender and have a foul-smelling odor. Twelve months ago she had episodes of painful swellings in the axillae that resolved with antibiotic therapy, leaving some scarring. She has Crohn disease. Menses occur at irregular 18- to 40-day intervals and last 1â€“5 days. The patient's only medication is mesalamine. She appears anxious. She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 87 kg (192 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right inframammary fold shows multiple tender, erythematous nodules, and fistulas with purulent discharge. Her fasting glucose concentration is 136 mg/dL. Which of the following areas is also likely affected by this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The forehead is commonly affected by acne vulgaris, which can also manifest with painful inflammatory nodules and scarring. However, acne vulgaris does not typically involve the inframammary or axillary folds, and fistulas draining malodorous pus are not expected. This patient has HS, which does not affect the face.
Image Description:

Disseminated papules, pustules, and comedones on an erythematous base are visible on the seborrheic skin of the patient's forehead.

These findings are consistent with moderate acne vulgaris.

B) INCORRECT:

The central part of the face is typically affected in rosacea, a condition commonly seen in women. Rosacea can manifest with erythematous papules and pustules; however, tender nodules with draining fistulas are not expected. Moreover, rosacea does not affect the axilla or breast. This patient has HS, which does not involve the face.
Image Description:

Papules, pustules, and erythema can be seen on the forehead, nose, and cheeks. A coarse, erythematous, and enlarged bulbous nose (rhinophyma) is also visible.

C) CORRECT:

Areas of intertriginous folds with hormonally active apocrine sweat glands, such as the groin, axilla, inner thigh, and perineal area, are most commonly involved in patients with HS. HS is a chronic inflammatory condition thought to be caused by blockage of the folliculopilosebaceous unit. The highest incidence of HS is seen in young women. Risk factors such as smoking, obesity, impaired glucose tolerance, inflammatory bowel disease, and a family history of HS are associated with a more severe disease course. Initial treatment consists of general skincare measures (e.g., gentle skin cleansing, wound care), behavioral interventions (e.g., weight loss, smoking cessation), and topical and/or oral antibiotics. If necessary, surgical interventions are performed to drain nodules and excise existing fistulas, scars, and abscesses.
Image Description:

Multiple suppurative lumps and erythema in the axilla. Intertriginous skin is a classic site of predilection.

D) INCORRECT:

The shin is commonly involved in pyoderma gangrenosum (PG), a condition associated with Crohn disease. PG manifests with very painful, rapidly progressive, red spots that can change into purulent pustules or deep ulcerated lesions with central necrosis. Inflammatory nodules with draining fistulas are not expected. Moreover, PG does not affect the axilla or breast. This patient has HS, which does not involve the shin.
Image Description:

A purulent ulcerative lesion with central necrosis and erythematous borders is visible on this patient's shin. The surrounding tissue appears to be swollen.

These findings are consistent with pyoderma gangrenosum, which most commonly affects the lower extremities.

E) INCORRECT:

The back is commonly affected by acne vulgaris, which can also manifest with painful inflammatory nodules and scarring. However, acne vulgaris does not typically involve the inframammary or axillary folds, and fistulas draining malodorous pus are not expected. This patient has HS, which does not affect the back.
Image Description:

Cysts, nodules, papules and comedones (including multiple healed lesions with visible scarring) are visible on this patient's upper back.
questions.hint: In a woman with obesity, inflammatory, painful axillary and inframammary lumps associated with scarring and fistulas that drain malodorous pus suggest hidradenitis suppurativa (HS).

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man presents to establish care with a new primary care provider. His medical history is notable for 2 years of pain and pustules in his groin and axillae. He describes cycles of pustules that coalesce together, drain considerable malodorous fluid, and then heal with scarring. His pediatrician had prescribed several antibiotic regimens, which provided some transient improvement, but the lesions have consistently recurred. Previous bacterial cultures of drained fluid have been negative.
The patient has a BMI of 31, is otherwise healthy, and takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 5 years.
Physical examination of the axillae and groin reveals papules and nodules draining purulent fluid on a background of sinus tracts and cribriform scarring (figure).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Epidermal inclusion cysts occur when keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium becomes embedded below the epidermis, leading to accumulation of keratinous material within a walled-off cavity. These cysts may rupture and become inflamed, but they are typically discrete lesions and do not have a predilection for intertriginous regions.

B) CORRECT:

Hidradenitis suppurativa is a disorder of follicular occlusion that affects intertriginous regions of the body, usually the axillae, groin, and inframammary folds. It occurs in roughly 1% of the general population. The strongest risk factor is a family history of hidradenitis suppurativa (present in 40% of patients). Additionally, there are modifiable risk factors, such as cigarette smoking and obesity, both of which are reported for this patient.

Hidradenitis suppurativa manifests with inflamed papules and nodules that may collect into indurated or boggy abscesses and drain considerable fluid. Bacterial culture of the fluid is often sterile, although superinfection is possible. Manifestations of more-severe disease include characteristic cribriform or sievelike scarring, double-ended pseudocomedones, and coalescing sinus tracts. The scarring, drainage, and pain associated with hidradenitis suppurativa can substantially affect quality of life.

The therapeutic ladder for hidradenitis suppurativa begins with risk-factor modification, including weight loss and smoking cessation. For mild disease, topical agents such as benzoyl peroxide, chlorhexidine washes, or topical clindamycin may be used. Patients with more-extensive disease usually require chronic antimicrobial regimens that have an antiinflammatory effect, such as doxycycline; antiandrogenic therapies such as spironolactone; or tumor necrosis factor-alpha inhibitors. Surgical excision is an option after medical management has been exhausted and may lead to remission for some patients.

Key learning point: Hidradenitis suppurativa is a disorder of follicular occlusion that manifests with painful, purulent papules and nodules; abscess and sinus-tract formation; and scarring in intertriginous regions.

C) INCORRECT:

Folliculitis occurs when follicular occlusion leads to inflammation of a superficial hair follicle, often from localized infection. This condition would not be expected to affect exclusively intertriginous areas and cause the scarring and sinus-tract formation that this patient exhibits.

D) INCORRECT:

Pilonidal sinus disease may also manifest as inflamed sinuses or cysts, but it is usually isolated to the superior gluteal fold and would not be expected to affect the axillae.

E) INCORRECT:

Furunculosis represents abscess formation from deep infection of a hair follicle. In some cases, it may resemble hidradenitis suppurativa, but concurrent involvement of the groin and axillae would be unlikely. Furthermore, culture of fluid from the lesion is usually positive.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman presents with six months of painful swellings in both axillae. Each lesion begins as a tender bump that enlarges and sometimes drains a thick, malodorous fluid. She has similar swellings in her groin. She denies any preceding trauma or systemic symptoms. Attempts with topical ointments have provided only temporary relief. Examination shows multiple scars and interconnected tracts in the involved areas.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lymphogranuloma venereum typically presents with a transient genital lesion followed by unilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. The chronic, bilateral lesions with sinus tracts and malodorous drainage in this patient do not align with the lymphatic spread and localized buboes characteristic of this condition.

B) CORRECT:

Hidradenitis suppurativa manifests with chronic, painful nodules in intertriginous areas such as the axillae and groin. These nodules can progress to abscesses and form sinus tracts, leading to scarring. The condition originates from follicular occlusion and dysregulation, allowing secondary bacterial colonization. This results in thick, malodorous drainage and a chronic, relapsing course. The inflammatory process disrupts follicular integrity, causing the characteristic clinical features.

Key learning point: Hidradenitis suppurativa is a chronic skin condition characterized by painful nodules and discharging sinuses, primarily affecting areas with apocrine sweat glands such as the axillae.
Image Description:

Multiple suppurative lumps and erythema in the axilla. Intertriginous skin is a classic site of predilection.

C) INCORRECT:

Carbuncles are clusters of furuncles caused by bacterial infection, often Staphylococcus aureus. They present acutely with tenderness and systemic symptoms, typically on the neck or back. The chronic, bilateral lesions with sinus tracts and scarring in this patient suggest a different, ongoing inflammatory process rather than an acute infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous tuberculosis can present with nodular or plaque-like lesions that ulcerate, but it does not typically involve bilateral, recurrent lesions in apocrine-rich areas like the axillae and groin. The absence of systemic symptoms and the pattern of malodorous lesions evolving from nodules to abscesses suggest an inflammatory process rather than a mycobacterial infection.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of worsening axillary pain. She denies fever, chills, or systemic symptoms. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination findings are shown. Review of systems is significant for similar episodes in bilateral axillae and groin over the past 18 months, with some lesions spontaneously draining before healing. What is the most appropriate management approach?

choices.text: Incision and drainage with antibiotic prophylaxis
Bacterial culture and empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics
Warm compresses, topical clindamycin, and primary care follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage may provide temporary relief, but almost all lesions will recur after this procedure.

B) INCORRECT:

Bacterial culture is only indicated in patients with fever or signs of cellulitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical excision is reserved for extensive, chronic disease with scarring and is not indicated for acute manifestations of individual lesions.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with recurrent painful nodules in intertriginous areas, indicating hidradenitis suppurativa. For mild disease, initial management includes supportive care with warm compresses and first-line topical antibiotic therapy. Primary care follow-up is appropriate to monitor response and evaluate for further management.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral retinoids such as isotretinoin have limited efficacy and are used as second-line or third-line treatments in hidradenitis suppurativa. Retinoids may be preferred in patients with concurrent severe acne vulgaris, but that condition is not present here.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 4-year history of recurrent, painful, draining nodules in her bilateral axillae. She notes the lesions have resulted in significant scarring. She smokes one pack of cigarettes daily. Physical examination reveals tender, erythematous nodules, along with fibrotic scars in both axillae. Which of the following additional findings is typical for this patient's underlying condition?

choices.text: Midline pits in the gluteal cleft
A central punctum on a mobile subcutaneous nodule
Open comedones with two or more openings
Linear burrows in the interdigital web spaces

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pits in the intergluteal cleft are characteristic of pilonidal disease. This is a chronic inflammatory condition caused by hair penetrating the skin in the sacrococcygeal region, leading to sinus or abscess formation. While it involves hair follicles, its location and specific findings are distinct from the patient's presentation in the axillae.

B) INCORRECT:

A central punctum on a mobile subcutaneous nodule is typical of an epidermoid cyst. The punctum represents the opening of the occluded hair follicle from which the cyst originated. Although these can become inflamed and painful, they are typically solitary, mobile lesions and do not form the interconnected sinus tracts and extensive scarring seen in this patient's axillae.

C) CORRECT:

A typical finding for HS is the presence of double-ended comedones, also known as tombstone comedones. These are open comedones that have two or more surface openings connecting to a single, dilated follicle subcutaneously. Their presence is highly specific for HS and helps distinguish it from recurrent furunculosis or abscesses. Other characteristic lesions include sinus tracts and hypertrophic or atrophic scars. The underlying pathophysiology of HS involves follicular occlusion and subsequent rupture, leading to a profound inflammatory response.

D) INCORRECT:

Pustules centered on hair follicles describe folliculitis, which is inflammation of the hair follicle, often due to infection with Staphylococcus aureus. While HS involves follicular inflammation, and secondary infection is common, the presence of simple pustules is non-specific. The patient's history of chronic, recurrent, deep-seated nodules with extensive scarring points to a diagnosis other than simple folliculitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Linear burrows in the interdigital web spaces are a pathognomonic finding for scabies, an infestation caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei. The mite burrows into the epidermis to lay eggs, creating these characteristic lesions. The lesion morphology for scabies is inconsistent with the patient's painful, draining axillary nodules.
questions.hint: This patient's history of recurrent, painful, draining nodules in intertriginous areas and extensive scarring is typical of hidradenitis suppurativa (HS).
